meta.title: Hacking with Python: Your Guide to Ethical Hacking, Basic Security, Penetration Testing, and Python Hacking - Hacking Made Easy
meta.author: Evan Lane

parts.title: Hacking Defined and Discussed
parts.body: "Hacking Defined and Discussed" – The introduction clarifies hacking's negative connotations, like stealing info, but also its positive role in network defense. The book introduces key topics, such as differing hacker types: black hat (malicious), white hat (protective), and grey hat (curious/neutral). Readers will learn foundational hacking skills using Python, emphasizing the importance of ethical practices over illegal system access. This educational guide aims to demystify hacking, providing insight into basic techniques and ways to safeguard personal networks against intruders.

parts.title: Weakest Link: Password Security
parts.body: Hackers often target passwords as the weakest security link. If not obtained through social engineering or physical access, hackers use tools like Cain and Abel, John the Ripper, and RainbowCrack. These tools need physical access to the target system for efficiency. Passwords are protected using one-way hashes, making them difficult for hackers to decipher. Linux systems add complexity by using salt to randomize hashes.

parts.title: Evil Twin Attack Setup and Execution
parts.body: Setting up an Evil Twin Attack involves creating a fake Wi-Fi access point that looks legitimate. Hackers use this to trick users into connecting to it so they can intercept and monitor traffic. The process involves using tools like Airmon-ng, Airdump-ng, and Airbase-ng to start up and conduct this attack, requiring patient waiting for targets to connect and then capturing their information. Deauthenticating targets from their current networks and ensuring the strongest signal ensures that they connect to the hacker’s fake network.
